6.description: Starting to establish a history of suspicious or risky behavior.

99.description: The reputation score is not mapped. See the rep_score attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Very Safe

2.caption: Safe

10.description: Proven evidence of maliciousness.

type.description:
The vulnerability type as selected from a large dropdown menu during CVE refinement.

Most frequently used vulnerability types are: DoS, Code Execution, Overflow, Memory Corruption, Sql Injection, XSS, Directory Traversal, Http Response Splitting, Bypass something, Gain Information, Gain Privileges, CSRF, File Inclusion. For more information see Vulnerabilities By Type distributions.
type.caption: Vulnerability Type

title.description: A title or a brief phrase summarizing the CVE record.
title.caption: Title

product.description: The product where the vulnerability was discovered.
product.caption: Product

desc.description: A brief description of the CVE Record.
desc.caption: Description

uid.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures unique number assigned to a specific computer vulnerability. A CVE Identifier begins with 4 digits representing the year followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CVE-2021-12345.
uid.caption: CVE ID

references.description: A list of reference URLs with additional information about the CVE Record.
references.caption: References

created_time.description: The Record Creation Date identifies when the CVE ID was issued to a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) or the CVE Record was published on the CVE List. Note that the Record Creation Date does not necessarily indicate when this vulnerability was discovered, shared with the affected vendor, publicly disclosed, or updated in CVE.
created_time.caption: Created Time

cvss.description: The CVSS object details Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) scores from the advisory that are related to the vulnerability.
cvss.caption: CVSS Score

cwe.description: The CWE object represents a weakness in a software system that can be exploited by a threat actor to perform an attack. The CWE object is based on the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) catalog.
cwe.caption: CWE

cwe_uid.description: The Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) unique identifier. For example: CWE-787.
cwe_uid.caption: CWE UID

@deprecated.message: Use the cwe object attributes instead.

cwe_url.description: Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) definition URL. For example: https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/787.html.
cwe_url.caption: CWE URL

@deprecated.message: Use the cwe object attributes instead.

epss.description: The Exploit Prediction Scoring System (EPSS) object describes the estimated probability a vulnerability will be exploited. EPSS is a community-driven effort to combine descriptive information about vulnerabilities (CVEs) with evidence of actual exploitation in-the-wild. (EPSS).
epss.caption: EPSS

modified_time.description: The Record Modified Date identifies when the CVE record was last updated.
modified_time.caption: Modified Time

created_time_dt.description: The Record Creation Date identifies when the CVE ID was issued to a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) or the CVE Record was published on the CVE List. Note that the Record Creation Date does not necessarily indicate when this vulnerability was discovered, shared with the affected vendor, publicly disclosed, or updated in CVE.
created_time_dt.caption: Created Time

modified_time_dt.description: The Record Modified Date identifies when the CVE record was last updated.
modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time

name.description: The name of the metric.
name.caption: Name

The boundary of the connection, normalized to the caption of 'boundary_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary(same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

6.description: Through a virtual private gateway
6.caption: Virtual Private Gateway

99.description: The boundary is not mapped. See the boundary attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

1.caption: Localhost

2.description: Internal network traffic between two endpoints inside network.
2.caption: Internal

10.description: Through a gateway VPC endpoint (Nitro-based instances only)

9.caption: Local Gateway

The normalized identifier of the boundary of the connection.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary (same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.
boundary_id.caption: Boundary ID

3.description: Lateral network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the inside network.
3.caption: Lateral

99.description: The direction is not mapped. See the direction attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

1.caption: Inbound

direction_id.description: The normalized identifier of the direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email.
direction_id.caption: Direction ID

tcp_flags.description: The network connection TCP header flags (i.e., control bits).

name.description: The friendly name of the process, for example: Notepad++.
name.caption: Name

pid.description: The process identifier, as reported by the operating system. Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

session.description: The user session under which this process is running.
session.caption: Session

user.description: The user under which this process is running.
user.caption: User

group.description: The group under which this process is running.
group.caption: Group

tid.description: The Identifier of the thread associated with the event, as returned by the operating system.
tid.caption: Thread ID

uid.description: A unique identifier for this process assigned by the producer (tool).  Facilitates correlation of a process event with other events for that process.
uid.caption: Unique ID

loaded_modules.description: The list of loaded module names.
loaded_modules.caption: Loaded Modules

cmd_line.description: The full command line used to launch an application, service, process, or job. For example: ssh user@10.0.0.10. If the command line is unavailable or missing, the empty string '' is to be used
cmd_line.caption: Command Line

container.description: The information describing an instance of a container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.
container.caption: Container

created_time.description: The time when the process was created/started.
created_time.caption: Created Time

integrity.description: The process integrity level, normalized to the caption of the direction_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source (Windows only).

integrity_id.description: The normalized identifier of the process integrity level (Windows only).
integrity_id.caption: Integrity Level

lineage.description: The lineage of the process, represented by a list of paths for each ancestor process. For example: ['/usr/sbin/sshd', '/usr/bin/bash', '/usr/bin/whoami'].

namespace_pid.description: If running under a process namespace (such as in a container), the process identifier within that process namespace.
namespace_pid.caption: Namespace PID

parent_process.description: The parent process of this process object. It is recommended to only populate this field for the first process object, to prevent deep nesting.
parent_process.caption: Parent Process

sandbox.description: The name of the containment jail (i.e., sandbox). For example, hardened_ps, high_security_ps, oracle_ps, netsvcs_ps, or default_ps.

terminated_time.description: The time when the process was terminated.

xattributes.description: An unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs that represent a process extended attribute.
xattributes.caption: Extended Attributes

auid.description: The audit user assigned at login by the audit subsystem.
auid.caption: Audit User ID

euid.description: The effective user under which this process is running.
euid.caption: Effective User ID

egid.description: The effective group under which this process is running.
egid.caption: Effective Group ID

version.description: The CVSS version. For example: 3.1.
version.caption: Version

depth.description: The CVSS depth represents a depth of the equation used to calculate CVSS score.
depth.caption: CVSS Depth

severity.description:
The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) Qualitative Severity Rating. A textual representation of the numeric score.

CVSS v2.0
  • Low (0.0 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 6.9)
  • High (7.0 10.0)

CVSS v3.0
  • None (0.0)
  • Low (0.1 - 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 - 6.9)
  • High (7.0 - 8.9)
  • Critical (9.0 - 10.0)
severity.caption: Severity

metrics.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System metrics. This attribute contains information on the CVE's impact. If the CVE has been analyzed, this attribute will contain any CVSSv2 or CVSSv3 information associated with the vulnerability. For example: { {"Access Vector", "Network"}, {"Access Complexity", "Low"}, ...}.
metrics.caption: Metrics

base_score.description: The CVSS base score. For example: 9.1.
base_score.caption: Base Score

overall_score.description: The CVSS overall score, impacted by base, temporal, and environmental metrics. For example: 9.1.
overall_score.caption: Overall Score

vector_string.description: The CVSS vector string is a text representation of a set of CVSS metrics. It is commonly used to record or transfer CVSS metric information in a concise form. For example: 3.1/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:H.
vector_string.caption: Vector String

cvss.name: cvss
cvss.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) object provides a way to capture the principal characteristics of a vulnerability and produce a numerical score reflecting its severity.

name.description: The full name of the observable attribute. The name is a pointer/reference to an attribute within the event data. For example: file.name.
name.caption: Name

type.description: The observable value type name.
type.caption: Type

value.description:
The value associated with the observable attribute. The meaning of the value depends on the observable type.
If the name refers to a scalar attribute, then the value is the value of the attribute.
If the name refers to an object attribute, then the value is not populated.
value.caption: Value

3.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Media Access Control (MAC) address. For example: 18:36:F3:98:4F:9A.
3.caption: MAC Address

6.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Uniform Resource Locator (URL) string. For example: http://www.example.com/download/trouble.exe.
6.caption: URL String

99.description: The observable data type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which may contain data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

1.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Unique name assigned to a device connected to a computer network. A domain name in general is an Internet address that can be resolved through the Domain Name System (DNS). For example: r2-d2.example.com.
1.caption: Hostname

2.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Internet Protocol address (IP address), in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. For example, 192.168.200.24 or 2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334.
2.caption: IP Address

10.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Resource unique identifier. For example, S3 Bucket name or EC2 Instance ID.
10.caption: Resource UID

4.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
User name. For example: john_doe.
4.caption: User Name

5.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Email address. For example: john_doe@example.com.
5.caption: Email Address

7.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
File name. For example: text-file.txt.
7.caption: File Name

8.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Hash. A unique value that corresponds to the content of the file, image, ja3_hash or hassh found in the schema. For example MD5: 3172ac7e2b55cbb81f04a6e65855a628.
8.caption: Hash

9.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Process name. For example: Notepad.
9.caption: Process Name

20.description:
Observable by Object.
The Endpoint object describes a physical or virtual device that connects to and exchanges information with a computer network. Some examples of endpoints are mobile devices, desktop computers, virtual machines, embedded devices, and servers. Internet-of-Things deviceslike cameras, lighting, refrigerators, security systems, smart speakers, and thermostatsare also endpoints.
20.caption: Endpoint

21.description:
Observable by Object.
The User object describes the characteristics of a user/person or a security principal. Defined by D3FEND d3f:UserAccount.
21.caption: User

22.description:
Observable by Object.
The Email object describes the email metadata such as sender, recipients, and direction. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Email.
22.caption: Email

23.description:
Observable by Object.
The Uniform Resource Locator(URL) object describes the characteristics of a URL. Defined in RFC 1738 and by D3FEND d3f:URL.
23.caption: Uniform Resource Locator

24.description:
Observable by Object.
The File object represents the metadata associated with a file stored in a computer system. It encompasses information about the file itself, including its attributes, properties, and organizational details. Defined by D3FEND d3f:File.
24.caption: File

25.description:
Observable by Object.
The Process object describes a running instance of a launched program. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Process.
25.caption: Process

26.description:
Observable by Object.
The Geo Location object describes a geographical location, usually associated with an IP address. Defined by D3FEND d3f:PhysicalLocation.
26.caption: Geo Location

27.description:
Observable by Object.
The Container object describes an instance of a specific container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.
27.caption: Container

29.description:
Observable by Object.
The registry value object describes a Windows registry value.
29.caption: Registry Value

30.description:
Observable by Object.
The Fingerprint object provides detailed information about a digital fingerprint, which is a compact representation of data used to identify a longer piece of information, such as a public key or file content. It contains the algorithm and value of the fingerprint, enabling efficient and reliable identification of the associated data.
30.caption: Fingerprint

28.description:
Observable by Object.
The registry key object describes a Windows registry key. Defined by D3FEND d3f:WindowsRegistryKey.
28.caption: Registry Key

xattributes.description:
An unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs where each pair represents a file or folder extended attribute.

For example: Windows alternate data stream attributes (ADS stream name, ADS size, etc.), user-defined or application-defined attributes, ACL, owner, primary group, etc. Examples from DCS:

  • ads_name
  • ads_size
  • dacl
  • owner
  • primary_group
  • link_name - name of the link associated to the file.
  • hard_link_count - the number of links that are associated to the file.
xattributes.caption: Extended Attributes

This object encapsulates the necessary attributes and methods to construct and send DNS queries, specify the query type (e.g., A, AAAA, MX). Defined by D3FEND d3f:DNSLookup.

title.description: A title or a brief phrase summarizing the reported finding.

attacks.description: The MITRE ATT&CK速 technique and associated tactics related to the finding.

The time when the finding was first observed. e.g. The time when a vulnerability was first observed.

It can differ from the created_time timestamp, which reflects the time this finding was created.

last_seen_time.description:
The time when the finding was most recently observed. e.g. The time when a vulnerability was most recently observed.

It can differ from the modified_time timestamp, which reflects the time this finding was last modified.
last_seen_time.caption: Last Seen

modified_time.caption: Modified Time

product_uid.description: The unique identifier of the product that reported the finding.

related_analytics.description: Other analytics related to this finding.

related_events.description: Describes events and/or other findings related to the finding as identified by the security product.

src_url.description: The URL pointing to the source of the finding.

created_time_dt.description: The time when the finding was created.
created_time_dt.caption: Created Time

modified_time_dt.description: The time when the finding was last modified.
modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time

first_seen_time_dt.description:
The time when the finding was first observed. e.g. The time when a vulnerability was first observed.

It can differ from the created_time timestamp, which reflects the time this finding was created.
first_seen_time_dt.caption: First Seen

last_seen_time_dt.description:
The time when the finding was most recently observed. e.g. The time when a vulnerability was most recently observed.

It can differ from the modified_time timestamp, which reflects the time this finding was last modified.
last_seen_time_dt.caption: Last Seen

4.caption: Mapped

5.description: A module loaded in a non standard way. However, GetModuleFileName succeeds on this allocation.
5.caption: NonStandard Backed

args.description: The arguments sent along with the HTTP request.

version.description: The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) version.

length.description: The HTTP request length, in number of bytes.

uid.description: The unique identifier of the http request.

url.description: The URL object that pertains to the request.

http_headers.description: Additional HTTP headers of an HTTP request or response.

GET.description: The GET method requests a representation of the specified resource. Requests using GET should only retrieve data.
GET.caption: Get

HEAD.description: The HEAD method asks for a response identical to a GET request, but without the response body.
HEAD.caption: Head

POST.description: The POST method submits an entity to the specified resource, often causing a change in state or side effects on the server.

For example: ["network", "connection.ip:destination", "device.ip:source"]

log_level.description: The audit level at which an event was generated.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

logged_time_dt.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

modified_time_dt.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.

The subnet represented in a CIDR notation, using the format network_address/prefix_length. The network_address can be in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. The prefix length indicates the number of bits used for the network portion, and the remaining bits are available for host addresses within that subnet.
For example:
  • 192.168.1.0/24
  • 2001:0db8:85a3:0000::/64
subnet_t.caption: Subnet

The additional information from an external data source, which is associated with the event or a finding. For example add location information for the IP address in the DNS answers:

[{"name": "answers.ip", "value": "92.24.47.250", "type": "location", "data": {"city": "Socotra", "continent": "Asia", "coordinates": [-25.4153, 17.0743], "country": "YE", "desc": "Yemen"}}]

3.description: Action is required but the situation is not serious at this time.

6.description: An error occurred but it is too late to take remedial action.

1.caption: Informational

2.description: The user decides if action is needed.
2.caption: Low

5.description: Action is required immediately and the scope is broad.
5.caption: Critical

severity_id.description:
The normalized identifier of the event/finding severity.

The normalized severity is a measurement the effort and expense required to manage and resolve an event or incident. Smaller numerical values represent lower impact events, and larger numerical values represent higher impact events.
severity_id.caption: Severity ID

99.description: The action was not mapped. See the action attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

0.description: The action was unknown. The disposition_id attribute may still be set to a non-unknown value, for example 'Count', 'Uncorrected', 'Isolated', 'Quarantined' or 'Exonerated'.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: The activity was allowed. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Allowed', 'Approved', 'Delayed', 'No Action', 'Count' etc.
1.caption: Allowed

2.description: The attempted activity was denied. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Blocked', 'Rejected', 'Quarantined', 'Isolated', 'Dropped', 'Access Revoked, etc.
2.caption: Denied

action_id.description: The action taken by a control or other policy-based system leading to an outcome or disposition. Dispositions conform to an action of 1 'Allowed' or 2 'Denied' in most cases. Note that 99 'Other' is not an option. No action would equate to 1 'Allowed'. An unknown action may still correspond to a known disposition. Refer to disposition_id for the outcome of the action.
action_id.caption: Action ID

8.description: A request or submission was approved. For example, when a form was properly filled out and submitted. This is distinct from 1 'Allowed'.
8.caption: Approved

9.description: A quarantined file or other content was restored to its original location.
9.caption: Restored

11.description: A corrupt file or configuration was corrected.
11.caption: Corrected

14.description: An operation was delayed, for example if a restart was required to finish the operation.
14.caption: Delayed

15.description: Suspicious activity or a policy violation was detected without further action.
15.caption: Detected

18.description: A file or other entity was marked with extended attributes.

20.description: Counted the request or activity but did not determine whether to allow it or block it.

22.description: Required the end user to solve a CAPTCHA puzzle to prove that a human being is sending the request.
22.caption: Captcha

23.description: Ran a silent challenge that required the client session to verify that it's a browser, and not a bot.
23.caption: Challenge

24.description: The requestor's access has been revoked due to security policy enforcements. Note: use the Host profile if the User or Actor requestor is not present in the event class.
24.caption: Access Revoked

25.description: A request or submission was rejected. For example, when a form was improperly filled out and submitted. This is distinct from 2 'Blocked'.
25.caption: Rejected

26.description: An attempt to access a resource was denied due to an authorization check that failed. This is a more specific disposition than 2 'Blocked' and can be complemented with the authorizations attribute for more detail.
26.caption: Unauthorized

27.description: An error occurred during the processing of the activity or request. Use the message attribute of the base class for details.

13.description: A corrupt file or configuration was not corrected.

0.description: The action was unknown. The disposition_id attribute may still be set to a non-unknown value, for example 'Count', 'Uncorrected', 'Isolated', 'Quarantined' or 'Exonerated'.

1.description: The activity was allowed. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Allowed', 'Approved', 'Delayed', 'No Action', 'Count' etc.

2.description: The attempted activity was denied. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Blocked', 'Rejected', 'Quarantined', 'Isolated', 'Dropped', 'Access Revoked, etc.
2.caption: Denied

action_id.description: The action taken by a control or other policy-based system leading to an outcome or disposition. Dispositions conform to an action of 1 'Allowed' or 2 'Denied' in most cases. Note that 99 'Other' is not an option. No action would equate to 1 'Allowed'. An unknown action may still correspond to a known disposition. Refer to disposition_id for the outcome of the action.

24.description: The requestor's access has been revoked due to security policy enforcements. Note: use the Host profile if the User or Actor requestor is not present in the event class.
24.caption: Access Revoked

25.description: A request or submission was rejected. For example, when a form was improperly filled out and submitted. This is distinct from 2 'Blocked'.
25.caption: Rejected

26.description: An attempt to access a resource was denied due to an authorization check that failed. This is a more specific disposition than 2 'Blocked' and can be complemented with the authorizations attribute for more detail.

status_detail.description:
The details about the authentication request. For example, possible details for Windows logon or logoff events are:
  • Success
    • LOGOFF_USER_INITIATED
    • LOGOFF_OTHER
  • Failure
    • USER_DOES_NOT_EXIST
    • INVALID_CREDENTIALS
    • ACCOUNT_DISABLED
    • ACCOUNT_LOCKED_OUT
    • PASSWORD_EXPIRED
status_detail.caption: Status Details

4.description: A batch server logon, where processes may be executing on behalf of a user without their direct intervention.

5.description: A logon by a service or daemon that was started by the OS.

7.description: A user unlocked the device.
7.caption: Unlock

8.description: A user logged on to this device from the network. The user's password in the authentication package was not hashed.
8.caption: Network Cleartext

9.description: A caller cloned its current token and specified new credentials for outbound connections. The new logon session has the same local identity, but uses different credentials for other network connections.
9.caption: New Credentials

11.description: A user logged on to this device with network credentials that were stored locally on the device and the domain controller was not contacted to verify the credentials.

12.description: Same as Remote Interactive. This is used for internal auditing.

13.description: Workstation logon.

99.caption: Other

0.description: The action was unknown. The disposition_id attribute may still be set to a non-unknown value, for example 'Count', 'Uncorrected', 'Isolated', 'Quarantined' or 'Exonerated'.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: The activity was allowed. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Allowed', 'Approved', 'Delayed', 'No Action', 'Count' etc.
1.caption: Allowed

2.description: The attempted activity was denied. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Blocked', 'Rejected', 'Quarantined', 'Isolated', 'Dropped', 'Access Revoked, etc.
2.caption: Denied

action_id.description: The action taken by a control or other policy-based system leading to an outcome or disposition. Dispositions conform to an action of 1 'Allowed' or 2 'Denied' in most cases. Note that 99 'Other' is not an option. No action would equate to 1 'Allowed'. An unknown action may still correspond to a known disposition. Refer to disposition_id for the outcome of the action.
action_id.caption: Action ID

24.description: The requestor's access has been revoked due to security policy enforcements. Note: use the Host profile if the User or Actor requestor is not present in the event class.
24.caption: Access Revoked

25.description: A request or submission was rejected. For example, when a form was improperly filled out and submitted. This is distinct from 2 'Blocked'.
25.caption: Rejected

26.description: An attempt to access a resource was denied due to an authorization check that failed. This is a more specific disposition than 2 'Blocked' and can be complemented with the authorizations attribute for more detail.
26.caption: Unauthorized

1.description: The activity was allowed. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Allowed', 'Approved', 'Delayed', 'No Action', 'Count' etc.

2.description: The attempted activity was denied. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Blocked', 'Rejected', 'Quarantined', 'Isolated', 'Dropped', 'Access Revoked, etc.
2.caption: Denied

action_id.description: The action taken by a control or other policy-based system leading to an outcome or disposition. Dispositions conform to an action of 1 'Allowed' or 2 'Denied' in most cases. Note that 99 'Other' is not an option. No action would equate to 1 'Allowed'. An unknown action may still correspond to a known disposition. Refer to disposition_id for the outcome of the action.
action_id.caption: Action ID

action_id.description: The action taken by a control or other policy-based system leading to an outcome or disposition. Dispositions conform to an action of 1 'Allowed' or 2 'Denied' in most cases. 0.description: The action was unknown. The disposition_id attribute may still be set to a non-unknown value, for example 'Count', 'Uncorrected', 'Isolated', 'Quarantined' or 'Exonerated'.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: The activity was allowed. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Allowed', 'Approved', 'Delayed', 'No Action', 'Count' etc.
1.caption: Allowed

2.description: The attempted activity was denied. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Blocked', 'Rejected', 'Quarantined', 'Isolated', 'Dropped', 'Access Revoked, etc.
2.caption: Denied

action_id.description: The action taken by a control or other policy-based system leading to an outcome or disposition. Dispositions conform to an action of 1 'Allowed' or 2 'Denied' in most cases. Note that 99 'Other' is not an option. No action would equate to 1 'Allowed'. An unknown action may still correspond to a known disposition. Refer to disposition_id for the outcome of the action.

[{"name": "answers.ip", "value": "92.24.47.250", "type": "location", "data": {"city": "Socotra", "continent": "Asia", "coordinates": [-25.4153, 17.0743], "country": "YE", "desc": "Yemen"}}]

xattributes.description:
An unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs where each pair represents a file or folder extended attribute.

  • ads_name
  • ads_size
  • dacl
  • owner
  • primary_group

  • hard_link_count - the number of links that are associated to the file.

image.description: The image used as a template to run a container or virtual machine.
image.caption: Image

is_fix_available.description: Indicates if a fix is available for the reported vulnerability.
is_fix_available.caption: Fix Availability

metrics.description: The general purpose metrics associated with the event. See specific usage.
metrics.caption: Metrics

class_name.description: The event class name, as defined by class_uid value.
class_name.caption: Class

dce_rpc.description: The DCE/RPC object describes the remote procedure call system for distributed computing environments.
dce_rpc.caption: Distributed Computing Environment/Remote Procedure Call (DCE/RPC)

vulnerabilities.description: This object describes vulnerabilities reported in a security finding.
vulnerabilities.caption: Vulnerabilities

length.description: The HTTP response length, in number of bytes.
length.caption: Response Length

terminal.description: The Pseudo Terminal. Ex: the tty or pts value.
terminal.caption: Terminal

loaded_modules.description: The list of loaded module names.
loaded_modules.caption: Loaded Modules

bios_ver.description: The BIOS version. For example: LENOVO G5ETA2WW (2.62).
bios_ver.caption: BIOS Version

tactics.description: The Tactic object describes the tactic ID and/or tactic name that are associated with the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.
tactics.caption: Tactics

policy.description: Describes details of a policy. See specific usage.
policy.caption: Policy

last_login_time.description: The last time when the user logged in.
last_login_time.caption: Last Login

system_call.description: The system call that was invoked.
system_call.caption: System Call

ime.description: The Input Method Editor (IME) file name.
ime.caption: IME

cwe_url.description: Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) definition URL. For example: https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/787.html.
cwe_url.caption: CWE URL

@deprecated.message: Use the cwe object attributes instead.

exit_code.description: The exit code reported by a process when it terminates. The convention is that zero indicates success and any non-zero exit code indicates that some error occurred.
exit_code.caption: Exit Code

hypervisor.description: The name of the hypervisor running on the device. For example, Xen, VMware, Hyper-V, VirtualBox, etc.
hypervisor.caption: Hypervisor

fingerprint.description: The digital fingerprint associated with an object.
fingerprint.caption: Fingerprint

observables.description: The observables associated with the event or a finding.
observables.caption: Observables

is_mfa.description: Indicates whether Multi Factor Authentication was used during authentication.
is_mfa.caption: Multi Factor Authentication

ldap_dn.description: The X.500 Distinguished Name (DN) is a structured string that uniquely identifies an entry, such as a user, in an X.500 directory service For example, cn=John Doe,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com.
ldap_dn.caption: LDAP Distinguished Name

security_states.description: The current security states. See specific usage.
security_states.caption: Security States

risk_score.description: The risk score as reported by the event source.
risk_score.caption: Risk Score

lineage.description: The lineage of the process, represented by a list of paths for each ancestor process. For example: ['/usr/sbin/sshd', '/usr/bin/bash', '/usr/bin/whoami'].
lineage.caption: Lineage

smtp_to.description: The value of the SMTP envelope RCPT TO command.
smtp_to.caption: SMTP To

relay.description: The network relay that is associated with the event.
relay.caption: Relay

assignee_group.description: The details of the group assigned to an Incident.
assignee_group.caption: Assignee Group

fixed_in_version.description: The software package version in which a reported vulnerability was patched/fixed.
fixed_in_version.caption: Fixed In Version
